title: London congestion charge should be scrapped as it is no longer 'fit for purpose,' report warns
text:
Thursday 19 January 2017 07:04 BST Click to followThe Evening Standard The congestion charge is no longer working, an influential report has found Oli Scarff/Getty 
Sadiq Khan should bring in radical plans for ‘intelligent’ road user pricing to tackle growing congestion across London , an influential report said today. 
The London Assembly transport committee claimed the congestion charge was no longer “fit for purpose” and should be immediately reformed with the flat fee scrapped. 
Transport for London should then roll out a system where motorists paid more for driving at peak times of day, for longer, on the capital’s most gridlocked routes. 
The road user pricing scheme could be extended across London, including congested suburban town centres, rather than restricted to the centre as it is now. 
The committee warned the Mayor that delay was “not an option” as congestion on the capital’s roads was getting steadily worse, while the cost to the economy was a staggering £5.5 billion a year. 
Gridlock has been blamed on the increase in delivery vans and minicabs, rather than private car use, which has been falling. Roadworks, including for the cycle superhighways, are also a factor. 
Transport committee chair Caroline Pidgeon said: “Something dramatic has to be done about the enormous congestion problem on London’s roads. The issue is costing our city money and costing Londoners their health and wellbeing. A quarter of London traffic was at a complete halt during Tube strike 
“TfL is doing a lot to tackle congestion, but not enough. Road pricing would be a fairer approach as road users would pay according to how much they contribute to congestion. 
“Gridlocked London needs to start moving again and tinkering here and there is not going to achieve that. The time has come for the Mayor to take a look at road pricing before things get any worse.” 
The report, London Stalling, said that planned new charges for emissions, proposed road tolls and vehicle excise duty should be integrated into one single road pricing scheme. 
Minicabs, which are exempt from the C-charge, should also be included. 
The committee admitted the proposal would not be universally popular but published research showing that half of motorists would back it, with just a fifth against. 
The poll also found it had the potential to change driver behaviour by encouraging them to drive at less congested times or switch to public transport, cycling and walking. 
Other recommendations included reducing restrictions on night-time deliveries, bringing in a workplace parking levy and considering a ban on personal deliveries for staff at their workplace. 
The report said TfL should reconsider “click and collect” for online shopping at Tube and rail stations. 
It suggested more could be done to reduce the impact of roadworks, many of which were caused by TfL itself as it modernised the roads network. 
Business groups welcomed the road pricing proposal, with some caveats. 
Colin Stanbridge of the London Chamber of Commerce said: “The congestion charge no longer serves the purpose for which it was created and we would not oppose targeted charging in principle. 
“However our concern would be that businesses are not used as a money-spinner and any new scheme takes into account the economic value of a journey. 
“Excessive new congestion charging on delivery vehicles will end up reflected in prices that customers will pay”. More about:
